data.name: Transpiling C++ to Python Series 1
data.description: In this kata, C++ to Python transpiler is to be built, and as suggested by its name it is meant to help translate C++ source code into equivalent counterpart that follows the symbols and syntax adapted by Python. In this first series, the task is to design a class Tokenizer, which during instantiation takes in raw C++ source code string and has an instance method named getToken that returns instance of Token class. Example: //In C++ Tokenizer k = Tokenizer("2.34 + 1.23;"); Token tk = k.getToken(); *First iteration: Expect -> tk.getName() = "float"; tk.getSym() = "2.34"; *Second iteration: Expect -> tk.getName() = "add"; tk.getSym() = '+'; //In Python k = Tokenizer("#define C 3.456789") for i in range(4): tk = k.getToken() print (tk.getName(), ' : ', tk.getSym()) **Expected results** -> 'sharp : #' -> 'keyword : define' -> 'identifier : C' -> 'float : 3.456789' Token is a class used to represent each token resulted from the segmentation analysis. Its private attributes are name, which serves as label of the token and sym, which is the symbol of the token. Both are of string type in C++. Moreover, it also consists of the following public function members: getName : returns (string type) token's name getSym : returns (string type) token's symbol *To make the task more INTERESTING, commercial regex module (i.e. re in Python, and regex in C++) shall be prohibited. Basic Tokens of C++ The following are regular expressions of tokens used in C++: words : [a-zA-Z\_][a-zA-Z\_0-9]* integer : [0-9]+ float : [0-9]+\.[0-9]+ char : \'[^\']\' string : \"[^\"]+\" add : \+ sub : \- mul : \* div : \/ mod : \% xor : \^ bor : \| band : \& lor : \|\| land : \&\& rshift : \>\> lshift : \<\< bnot : \~ lnot : \! iadd : \+\= isub : \-\= imul : \*\= idiv : \/\= imod : \%\= ixor : \^\= ibor : \|\= iband : \&\= irshift : \>\>\= ilshift : \<\<\= ibnot : \~\= ne : \!\= eq : \=\= gt : \> lt : \< ge : \>\= le : \<\= lcb : \{ rcb : \} lsb : \[ rsb : \] lparen : \( rparen : \) period : \. arrow : \-\> comment : \/\/ mcl : \/\* mcr : \*\/ comma : \, sharp : \# ellipse : \.\.\. *NOTES: words, despite designated a general regular expression, have several categories, namely: a. Type => int, float, double, char, string, bool b. Modifier => short, long, signed, unsigned, const, mutable, volatile, inline, extern, virtual, static, auto, register, restrict, friend c. Accessor => public, protected, private d. Remaining => name should be the same as symbol => return, while, if, else, do, break, continue, switch, ...
